holiday_blurb: Global Love Day is an event celebrated with the goal of using love to transform the world. It was founded in 1999 with the belief that love is the most effective way to resolve global issues. On this day, people demonstrate love universally for one another in the spirit of peace and unity.

Brothers and Sisters Day is a day to honor and appreciate the bond between siblings. It was first created by HG Lewis in 1994 as a response to Mother's and Father's Day which often overshadow the importance of brother and sister relationships. Celebrate the day by spending quality time with your siblings and showing your love!

These eye-catching pastries are made from an airy, golden-brown dough and filled with sweet raspberry jam. With origins dating back to the late 1700s, these traditional English treats have been delighting sweet-toothed folks ever since. Enjoy yours with a cup of tea!

International Respect for Chickens Day is an annual celebration of chickens and an opportunity to highlight the tremendous contributions they make to our environment and our lives. It was first initiated in 2005 by United Poultry Concerns, an organization dedicated to the protection of chickens and other domestic fowl. This day celebrates compassionate and responsible treatment of chickens while raising awareness of why chickens deserve our respect.

National Hoagie Day is an annual celebration of the delicious classic sandwich. Every May 5th, Americans gather to enjoy the sandwich, which is rumored to have originated in Philadelphia in the early 1900s. Hoagies are the perfect way to celebrate the day with friends and family. Celebrate with a hoagie - it's a tradition!

National Beverage Day celebrates the joys of all beverages by indulging in your favourite drink from your favourite place. Enjoy a coffee, tea, hot chocolate, soda, or alcoholic beverage today to celebrate National Beverage Day. It's been around since the 1920's and has since become a tradition for beverage lovers everywhere to enjoy their favourite drinks on this special day!

Lemonade Day is an annual event empowering young people to create small entrepreneurial businesses. Through a series of workshops and resources, children are taught goal setting, business planning, and financial literacy. Founded in 2007, it has grown to serve millions of kids in thousands of cities worldwide.

Reward Yourself Day is a special occasion for taking a break from the hustle and bustle of daily life. Once in a while, it's important to pause and celebrate the enjoyment of life and all your hard work. Reward Yourself Day dates back to the 1950s and pamper yourself with a special treat: a pedicure, a spa day, a glass of wine, a quiet evening at home. You've earned

National Lost Sock Memorial Day is a day to commemorate all the beloved socks lost in the wash over the years. First established in 2016 by the Sock Manufacturers Association, the day is a chance to mourn the lost socks while wearing unmatched pairs to spread awareness of the cause!

This delicious holiday is a nod to the humble shrimp - from the ever-popular shrimp cocktail to the Southern, classic Cajun Boil, this day celebrates the flavorful crustacean. Celebrate by treating yourself to a special shrimp-based meal or dish, or simply happy shrimp day with friends!

Eat What You Want Day was created to celebrate and indulge in whatever makes you happy! Its origins come from the idea that life should be enjoyed and that you should be able to indulge every once in a while. Go ahead, enjoy that second slice of cake - it's Eat What You Want Day!

National Odometer Day celebrates the wheel’s role in tracking distances traveled. It commemorates Wilhelm Bruhn's invention of an odometer for wheeled vehicles in 1847. On this day, honor the odometer and celebrate all the places you've been with a road trip down memory lane. #NationalOdometerDay

What began as a small local gathering in Israel to celebrate the beloved chickpea dip, Hummus Day has become a truly international celebration of the delicious and nutritious dish. Every May 13th, people all around the world come together to show their appreciation for hummus, share recipes and stories, and to honor the history and rich cultural associations with the spreadable snack. Celebrate International Hummus Day by gathering with friends, cooking together and making a hummus dip that's out of

Dance Like a Chicken Day celebrates the moves of the strutting barnyard bird! It started in October 1940 when National Cluck-Cluck Day was created. This annual event has since become Dance Like a Chicken Day- an annual reminder to let your feathers down and dance!

Straw Hat Day celebrates the long-standing tradition of men wearing straw hats during the summer months. From the 1910s through the 1940s, most men would proudly sport a straw hat to remain cool in the sun. Today, Straw Hat Day has been revived for folks to celebrate and honor the timeless fashion accessory.

Celebrate National Mimosa Day on May 16th! This festive holiday commemorates the classic brunch cocktail of orange juice and sparkling wine. First created in Paris in 1925, this bubbly drink skirts the line between breakfast beverage and happy hour treat. Perfect for any occasion, don't forget the mimosa this National Mimosa Day!

This delicious holiday recognizes the sweet summer dessert, which is believed to have originated in the 18th century with the combination of tart cherries and sweet crumbly topping. Enjoy a bowl or plate of cherry cobbler on this scrumptious day!

This deliciously fluffy and cheesy dish has a long history, dating back to French haute cuisine in the late 18th century. This special day recognizes all the amazing variations of souffle including Gruyère cheese, fontina cheese, and even fish souffle! Enjoy your cheese souffle the traditional way or with a twist. Bon Appétit!

National Pizza Party Day celebrates and encourages everyone to host their own pizza party with friends and family. The day is celebrated on February 9th as the first known public pizza party was held on February 9th, 18th century in Bolivia. Gather your loved ones to create the ultimate pizza experience!

It's World Bee Day on May 20th! This holiday honors the essential role of bees in supporting biodiversity and agriculture. The day was declared in 2019 by the United Nations to recognize the importance of the decline of the global bee population. Pollinatorst are essential for food security and environmental health. Let's celebrate the hardworking bees and raise awareness of their plight! #WorldBeeDay

Celebrate National Ice Cream Day and indulge in your favorite flavors! History buffs can appreciate that the day commemorates President Ronald Reagan's 1985 proclamation recognizing ice cream as an important part of US culture and heritage. Make this July a sweet one with cold, creamy treats!

Buy a Musical Instrument Day celebrates the joy of music-making! It is an opportunity for aspiring musicians of all ages to join the symphony of sound-makers. Its history dates back to 1977 when the US Congress passed a bill in recognition of amateur musicians. Get out your credit cards and make some music! #BuyAMusicalInstrumentDay

National Taffy Day celebrates the classic, chewy delights of taffy! This festive day celebrates the history of taffy, which dates back to the early 1800s and has been a favorite of sweet fans ever since. Get ready for a day filled with flavorful candy!

Welcome to Scavenger Hunt Day - a day of exploration and discovery! Since the 1920s, scavenger hunts have been a fun way to explore new locations, solve puzzles, and unearth well-hidden treasures. Celebrate this special day by planning a virtual or in-person scavenger hunt to bring people together for an exciting challenge.

Geek Pride Day is an international celebration of geek culture on May 25th. This unofficial holiday was created in 2006 in Spain by the effort of blogger Jaime Conde-Salazar who wanted to celebrate and unify the growing community of geeks around the world. It is a day of awareness and appreciation for the non-mainstream pursuits of knowledge and skills.

Celebrate National Paper Airplane Day while honoring the history of paper airplanes. Learn the story behind this day, which dates back to 1957 when a paper airplane soared for a record-breaking flight of 26.1 seconds. Join the fun of making and flying paper planes. Take on challenges, enter competitions, and make your plane soar.

National Sunscreen Day is celebrated annually to raise awareness of using sunscreen to protect skin from the sun's ultraviolet (UV) rays. This celebration originated in Australia in 2002 and is now recognized around the world. Make sure to wear sunscreen to keep yourself and your skin healthy!

Celebrate National Hamburger Day every May 28th! What began as a way for the hamburger restaurant industry to celebrate its success back in 1952 has become an international holiday honoring one of the most popular foods on the planet. Get your buns ready for the tastiest day of the year - it'll be a burger-y good time!

National Paperclip Day celebrates the classic office supply and is held each year on May 29th. It commemorates the invention of the paperclip in 1901, when Norwegian inventor Johan Vaaler patented the “gem” paperclip. The project has also become a symbol of unity and solidarity, reminiscent of a time during World War II when Norwegians wore paperclips on their lapels to protest Nazi occupation.

International Hug Your Cat Day celebrates the unique bond between cats and their owners. Started in 2019, it's a day devoted to showing your furry feline how much you love them, usually with plenty of cuddles and kisses. Go ahead and make your cat's day by showing them some extra love!

National Macaroon Day celebrates the crunchy-on-the-outside, chewy-on-the-inside macaroon. The origin of this holiday is disputed, with some claiming it began in the 13th century with Italian Jews making macaroon-style cookies to welcome spring. Others say it originated in France in the 17th century. Either way, macaroons are delicious.

Ginger Cat Day celebrates cats with beautiful ginger fur! Ginger Cat Day has been celebrated since 2017, with the goal of raising awareness for all cats, but especially gingers, who can sometimes go overlooked at shelters. Celebrate with your own ginger cat, take time to volunteer at a shelter, or simply admire the beauty of these gorgeous cats!

National Cowgirl Day is an annual event that celebrates the spirit of the American West and its trailblazing cowgirls. Falling on the fourth Saturday of March, it honors the pioneering women who helped form the culture of the American West. From Annie Oakley to Stevie Nicks, National Cowgirl Day salutes these extraordinary women who blaze a path.

Classical Music Day celebrates the masterful works and genius of classical composers throughout history. From Bach to Beethoven, Mozart to Mendelssohn, these composers created some of the most beautiful and mesmerizing music in history. It serves as an annual reminder of the wonders of classical music and its powerful influence on culture and society.

Eat an Extra Dessert Day is a day to enjoy some extra sweetness! It began in 2018 as a fun holiday dedicated to being extra indulgent and celebrating a delicious treat. Whether you top your ice cream with extra sprinkles, get an extra-large slice of cake, or add an extra scoop of your favorite flavor, it’s the perfect day to enjoy a tasty dessert and have something extra sweet.

Celebrate cheesy goodness—it’s National Cheese Pizza Day! Every September 5th we revel in the savory wonders of pizza’s all-time favorite topping, cheese. Pizza itself is believed to have originated in Italy around the 10th century and cheese pizza has been around since the 1700s! Enjoy your cheese pizza today!

Great Egg Toss Day is a fun holiday that dates back to the Middle Ages. It is celebrated each year on Easter Monday and involves children throwing eggs to one another. The aim is to cover as much distance as possible before the egg breaks. Through this tradition, children can connect with each other over the age-old tradition, enjoy a bit of healthy competition, and have a splendid Easter day.

Neither Snow nor Rain Day celebrates the dedicated work of postal workers. It is celebrated annually on August 4 to honor the Post Office’s motto, derived from the Greek historian Herodotus: “Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.” Postal workers have consistently delivered mail throughout U.S. history, and this day is a fitting tribute to their hard work and dedication.

National Ampersand Day is a day to celebrate & recognize the punctuation character officially known as "the epericope," or the "and" sign. The celebration first began in the UK in 2008, and has since spread to other countries. Celebrate the & and embrace the ampersand.

Teddy Bear Day celebrates the bond between humans and their beloved stuffed animals. It is a day to honor the long-standing tradition of hugging, talking to, and loving stuffed animals as friends. Origins of this day are unclear, but it's likely related to the beloved US President Teddy Roosevelt, who famously refused to shoot a bear during a 1902 hunting trip.

This day honors the history of frozen food that revolutionized the way Americans cook and eat. On this day we pay tribute to the convenience and hearty meals in the TV dinner industry. Enjoy a classic favorite, and take a trip down memory lane!

National Make Your Bed Day is an annual celebration of tidying up. Originally founded in 2010 in Los Angeles, the special day encourages all to make their beds each morning and live each day with intention and purpose. Making your bed can be a small but powerful activity to begin the day on the right foot!

Are You OK Day is an annual national day of action organised to raise mental health awareness and reduce suicide. Its goal is to promote meaningful conversations and to reach out to people who may need help or just a listening ear. The day was founded in 2010 by the Menslink Charity, which supports young men and boys in Canberra, Australia.

Positive thinking day was founded in 1999 by author and professional speaker Sharon Loeschen to remind us of the power of gratitude and optimism. Take a moment to appreciate the people and things that bring joy to your life. Spread positive vibes and enjoy your day filled with positive vibes!

This day commemorates the famous German poet, playwright, and philosopher, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, and his birthday. The purpose of the day is to promote the German language and culture around the world. Educators, organizations, and students come together to celebrate this special day with activities such as reading competitions, public speaking contests, and creative writing workshops. Additionally, German Language Day is an important source of awareness and dialogue about the value

Make A Hat Day is a fun-filled celebration of creativity and self-expression. It encourages its participants to create their own unique and beautiful hats with whatever materials are available. It has been held on the third Sunday of August since its founding in 1996. Make A Hat Day celebrates the joy of making something by hand and putting a unique twist on fashion.

National Guacamole Day celebrates one of the most popular and beloved avocados-based dishes. Its origin story is full of lore and mystery. One story claims that it dates back to the 16th century when the Aztecs created a similar dish called "ahuaca-mulli" which is made of the same ingredients. Regardless, it has become a beloved dish all around the world. Celebrate with some fresh guac!

National Table Shuffleboard Day celebrates the classic game of strategy and skill, invented in 15th century England. Players from all over the world take to their tables to enjoy a friendly game of knockout shuffleboard. Whether it's a porch table or a fancy club game, celebrate with a shuffleboard contest!

Celebrate National Cheeseburger Day every September 18th! First introduced in 1924 at the University of California in Los Angeles, the cheeseburger has been the most popular burger in America for decades. Enjoy your favorite cheeseburger for lunch or dinner and share the love!

Meow Like a Pirate Day celebrates the parodied union of lovable cats and boisterous pirates. Every year, cat owners encourage their fuzzy comrades to meow like salty sailors with hopes of uncovering hidden treasure. The day was founded in 2001 by an Arizonan woman with an affinity for swashbuckling felines.

Celebrate National Queso Day with friends and family! This cheesy day of celebration was started in 2011 by Texas journalist John Vucetich and Quesoff, an annual queso competition held in Austin, Texas. Get creative with your queso recipes and show off your cheesy creations!

Miniature Golf Day celebrates the beloved miniature golf courses that have been providing family fun for generations. It's a chance to honor the tradition of playing a competitive game on a mini golf course while enjoying the great outdoors. Though its exact origin is unknown, miniature golf is believed to have started in Scotland in the late 19th century and has evolved into a beloved pastime. So grab those clubs, hit the course, and celebrate Miniature Golf Day!

National White Chocolate Day is an annual holiday that is devoted to the creamy, sugary, and delicious treat. White chocolate was first created in Switzerland in the 1930s and has since become a popular part of celebrations and desserts. This day is a big hit among chocolate lovers everywhere!

International Day of Sign Languages honors the importance of sign languages in the deaf community. Established in 2018 by the United Nations, this day celebrates the right of deaf people to access their native language. Sign languages transit hope, culture and identity for many who use them as their primary form of communication.

Bluebird of Happiness Day is an annual celebration of hope and optimism, encouraging us to focus on the good things in life. The tradition is said to stem from an old children's fable, where a small boy treks to find the Bluebird of Happiness, a symbol of joy and contentment. Today, the celebration of Bluebird of Happiness Day reminds us to look for, and relish, the wonder and beauty of life.

It is a day to celebrate and appreciate the art of cooking and culinary appreciation. Its history dates back to the beginning of the twentieth century, when the concept of home cooking was first deemed important to a family’s health. Today, it is celebrated with home-cooked meals, recipes, and baking. Celebrate National Cooking Day by cooking up something special!

National Pancake Day is a day for people to enjoy and celebrate the deliciousness of pancakes! Celebrated on the Tuesday before Ash Wednesday, it has its roots going back to the 17th century in the Christian tradition of Pancake Tuesday or Shrove Tuesday. Celebrate the day with family and friends by making pancakes!

Crush A Can Day is an annual event to raise awareness for recycling and sustainability. Started in 2005 in Colorado, it encourages everyone to celebrate the power of recycling by taking part in a can-crushing ceremony. Every August, gather friends, family, and even your local government to crush a few cans and mark the occasion. Celebrate sustainability and the environment today! #CrushACanDay

National Good Neighbor Day is an annual celebration honoring the importance of being a good neighbor. People are encouraged to perform selfless acts of kindness such as mowing a lawn or offering a helping hand. It is celebrated every September 28th and was founded in the 1970s by Becky Mattson of Lakeside, Montana.

Celebrate National Coffee Day and enjoy a cup of your favorite brew! Established in 2005, National Coffee Day recognizes the significance of coffee and the powerful impact it has on cultures around the world. Celebrate with friends, family, or just some much-deserved time alone with a fresh cup of joe!

National Chewing Gum Day celebrates America's favorite sweet treat! The day was created in the early 1990s by school administrators in Connecticut to recognize bubble blowing as an educational activity - a fun way to encourage students to learn. National Chewing Gum Day is now celebrated each year and is a day to enjoy the tasty treat and the creativity it encourages. So, grab a stick of gum and start munching!

Celebrate the world's funniest day, International Joke Day! Each year, people from all corners of the globe ‘yuk it up’ sharing their best belly laughs. Ever since its beginning in 1976, International Joke Day has been cherished for its pure silliness!

I Forgot Day is an unofficial holiday celebrated every year. The goal is to take this day to remember those tasks, projects, and birthdays we tend to forget. It was first celebrated in the early 2000s by a group of friends in Las Vegas, Nevada.

National Eat Beans Day is an annual event to honor the nutritional benefits of beans and all the delicious recipes that include them! It is also a chance to learn more about the great benefits beans can bring to your healthy lifestyle. The holiday started in 2019, thanks to the United Nations which chose beans as their chosen "supercrop."

Invisible Day is a day dedicated to exploring the power of perception. On this day, people are encouraged to honour unparalleled experiences and encourage awareness of mental health. Invisible Day was created in 2017 as a platform to bring attention to mental health and promote empathy and understanding.

Celebrate your writing tool of choice on Mechanical Pencil Day! It commemorates the invention of the mechanical pencil in 1822, when a German inventor patented a pencil with a lead cylinder and an internal mechanism for propelling the lead. Celebrate by using your favorite mechanical pencil or treating yourself to a new one!

National Fried Chicken Day is celebrated annually in honor of one of America’s favorite foods! Fried chicken has been around since the 1700s, when Scottish immigrants introduced it to the US and combined it with traditional African seasonings and southern cooking methods. Today, fried chicken is enjoyed throughout the world in all sorts of delicious recipes. So celebrate National Fried Chicken Day by indulging your love of fried chicken!

National Dive Bar Day is an annual celebration of dive bars across the country. Originating in 2007 as an effort to draw attention to the distinctive charm of these unique establishments, Dive Bar Day recognizes dive bar patrons and their favorite hangouts. Cheers to these local gems!

Be a Kid Again Day is an opportunity to step back in time and reconnect with the innocent joy of childhood. Put away your worries for a day and go outside and pretend, play tag, explore, and just have fun! Originally created in 1991 by a group of teachers, Be a Kid Again Day continues to be celebrated annually.

National Sugar Cookie Day is a sweet holiday that honors a classic favorite treat. Made with ingredients like flour, sugar, butter, and sometimes eggs, sugar cookies have a long history. According to lore, the first recipes for sugar cookies appeared in print as early as the eighteenth century in Germany and the Netherlands. Today, sugar cookies come in a variety of shapes, sizes, and flavors, and National Sugar Cookie Day is the perfect day to try them

AC Appreciation Day is a celebratory event to honor the invention of air conditioning. Every year, people across the globe remember the life-changing invention of air conditioning and its maintenance personnel. The first modern air conditioning unit was patented in 1902, revolutionizing the world before us! Let's all take a few minutes to show our appreciation! #AirConditioningAppreciationDay

Celebrated each year in the US, National State Fair Food Day pays tribute to classic faire from every corner of the country. With traditional treats like funnel cakes, corn dogs and deep-fried twinkies, it's a great way to explore regional flavors without leaving your kitchen. Dating back to the mid-1800s, state fairs featured a bounty of delectable delights - and National State Fair Food Day celebrates this beloved tradition.

National French Fry Day is an annual celebration of the beloved crispy snack. Dating back to the 17th century, French fries have become a staple food item all around the world. Gather your friends and fry up some potatoes in honor of this potato-filled holiday!

Beef Tallow Day is an informal holiday celebrated annually and celebrates beef fat’s many uses, from cooking to baking, from making candles to moisturizing skin, and even as fuel. Historically, beef fat was an essential part of early settlers’ diets, when resources were scarce and available fridges were far in the future.

Pandemonium Day is a wild celebration of community spirit! Each year, thousands of revelers flock to the city centre to enjoy a carnival-like atmosphere with live music, food and fun activities. The festivities stem from an ancient tradition dating back to the Roman period when people would offer sacrifices to ward off evil spirits. It's a time for joyfulness and chaos!

Orange Chicken Day is an annual celebration of a sweet & savory Chinese-style dish. It is believed to have originated in the USA during the 1980s, though its exact origins remain uncertain. Pay tribute to this classic dish by sharing your favorite orange chicken recipe - or even a take-out order - with your friends and family. Celebrate Orange Chicken Day!

World Snake Day is a day dedicated to recognizing the importance of snakes in their natural habitats. It was first designated in 2006, and is used to educate people around the world about seven unique species of snakes. World Snake Day acknowledges their beauty and complexity, and aims to bring awareness to the need for their protection.

National Tattoo Day is a day to celebrate body art, with a focus on honoring the skills of the tattoo artist. It is celebrated on July 17th annually, selected as it marked the day in 1961 when the British Tattoo Council was established, becoming one of the first organizations to regulate the industry. Celebrate with a new ink or show your support to your favorite artists!

World Listening Day is an annual event celebrated on July 18th to bring awareness to the power of listening. This day began in 2009 as a way to honor the late soundscape ecologist and artist, Gordon Hempton. It is celebrated by sound walks, field recordings, and sound art activities, all inspired by a shared appreciation for the acoustic environment.

National Hot Dog Day's origins trace back to the 1860s, when German immigrants introduced the food to the United States. Today, hot dogs are a popular food across the world, and the day is a great way to sample all sorts of flavors and global varieties. Celebrate with a cook-out and plenty of hot dogs with all the toppings. It's the perfect day to swap stories and celebrate the summertime staple! #NationalHotDog

National Moon Day celebrates the first lunar landing in 1969 when Neil Armstrong took "one giant leap for mankind" as he stepped onto the moon's surface. It is observed every year as a reminder of the success of the Apollo 11 mission and the hard work that went into making the historic event possible.

National Junk Food Day celebrates all the yummy and indulgent snacks that are loved around the world. It was started in the mid-1900s by a group of people who wanted to recognize the spontaneous joys that junk food brings. Today, it is celebrated annually with a relaxed, guilt-free appreciation for snacks like chips, chocolates, and candy bars.

Celebrate National Hammock Day to appreciate the lazy days of summer! Hang your hammock to observe the day, established in 1934 to honor HAMMOCKCO founder Abraham Lazyday's relentless dedication to hammocks. Enjoy relaxing in comfort and celebrate a timeless summer tradition!

Mosquito Day celebrates the success of controlling mosquito-borne diseases, such as malaria and yellow fever. It was originally celebrated in 1906 to honor the work of Dr. Fred Soper, who developed the program that eventually helped to wipe out malaria from the Americas. On Mosquito Day, we honor and celebrate the legacy of this incredible health achievement.

Celebrate National Tequila Day with a toast to tradition! Since the 16th century, tequila has been produced in the region around the city of Tequila, Jalisco, Mexico. Enjoy responsibly and remember to always have a grand lime and salt accompaniment! Cheers!

Carousel Day is an annual celebration of the historic carousels in the US that take place in cities and towns across the country. It began in 1895 with the establishment of the National Carousel Association, and as a way to celebrate carousel enthusiasts and their favorite pastime. The festival includes fun activities like carousel rides, carnival games, food, and fireworks displays. Carousel Day is a unique way to honor and take advantage of these beloved machines.

National All or Nothing Day was created as a way to encourage risk taking and embracing uncertainty, recognizing that even taking a chance and failing can lead to learning and growth. It’s a great day to take a leap of faith in pursuit of achieving a goal, regardless of how far out of reach it may appear.

Chicken Finger Day is a day to celebrate everyone's favorite fried treats! Popularized in the 1970's, chicken fingers have become a well loved snack and entrée. Celebrate by snacking on some golden-brown tenders or inventing a delicious new dipping sauce!

Celebrate the sweet, nourishing goodness of chocolate milk on National Chocolate Milk Day! Believed to be of Aztec origin, chocolate milk has been around since the 16th century, and has since become a global favorite!

National Lipstick Day is an annual event held every year to celebrate the much-loved cosmetic. It honours the impact lipstick has had on society for over 100 years, and encourages people to ‘rock their shades’ proudly. The celebration is thought to have begun in the early 2000s as a way to pay homage to the time-honoured tradition of wearing lipstick.

World Snorkeling Day is celebrated annually and was started in 2015 by the founders of Blue Ocean Network as a way to bring attention to the ocean conservation movement, while engaging individuals in an activity they can enjoy at their local beach. Snorkeling has been found to reduce stress, improve cardiovascular health, and is a great way to increase awareness of ocean conservation. Celebrate this day by getting outside and enjoying the world beneath the waves!

Celebrate National Avocado Day on July 31st! An unofficial holiday created in the 1990s in California, Avocado Day celebrates the crop's status as a flavorful, healthy and versatile food. Celebrate with guacamole, a delicious green smoothie, or try something new like an avocado roll! #AvocadoDay

National Handmade Day celebrates the creativity and craftsmanship of makers and small businesses worldwide. Founded in 2016, the holiday is a reminder to shop locally and support makers who are often overlooked by large corporations. Each year, the movement continues to grow, bringing makers, entrepreneurs, and shoppers together for a day of appreciation.

holiday_name: National Peanut Butter and Jelly Day
holiday_blurb: National Peanut Butter and Jelly Day is celebrated each year and honors a classic combination loved by kids and adults alike. This mouthwatering staple has been both nourishing and comforting generations since World War II, when peanut butter was used as a low-cost source of protein for service people. Today National Peanut Butter and Jelly Day is celebrated around the country by enjoying the beloved sandwich.

World Party Day is a celebration of joy, friendship and unity. Every year, people around the globe come together to raise money for important causes, revel in cultural diversity and dance for peace. It has been celebrated since the mid-1980s and continues to spread joy and hope around the world.

Carrot Day is celebrated worldwide on April 4th! It’s a day to recognize both health and culture, as carrots are a key ingredient in many cuisines and have been grown by farmers around the world for thousands of years. Enjoy some carrots today and maybe try a new recipe? Support local farmers and promote healthy nutrition!

Celebrate National Deep Dish Pizza Day with this classic and delicious American restaurant favorite. Enjoy a slice of Chicago-style, thick-crust pizza with a wide variety of topping combinations. Deep dish pizzas became popular in the 1940s when restaurants in the Midwest began offering the dish as an alternative to the thin-crust Italian-style pies.

National Siamese Cat Day, celebrated annually, honors these regal, blue-eyed felinesthat have been with us since the 14th century. Known for their intelligence and sociability, Siamese cats are well loved by their eccentric owners. Let's take a day to appreciate them!

National Beer Day is a day to raise a toast and celebrate beer! Every April 7th, beer lovers commemorate the day in 1933 when President Roosevelt signed the Cullen-Harrison Act, which legalized the sale and consumption of beer with an alcohol content of 3.2% or less. Cheers to appreciating a good beer! #NationalBeerDay

Zoo Lovers Day is a holiday to celebrate wildlife and the people who work with and care for them. It began in the early 19th century in response to increased interest in wildlife and shows appreciation for their conservation and study. Celebrate by visiting a zoo, participating in a conservation event, or simply showing kindness to animals around you!

International ASMR Day is celebrated around the world every year. It's a day to recognize and appreciate ASMR as a form of alternative therapy for people who find it helpful to relax and reduce stress. It was first celebrated in 2020 with the goal of bringing awareness to ASMR and its potential healing benefits.

National Hug Your Dog Day is celebrated each year and was created to honor the special bond between owners and their canine companions. This special day is a reminder to take time out of our busy lives to show our furry friends how much we care. The holiday was founded in 2006 with the goal of spreading awareness of the importance of responsible pet ownership.

National Pet Day is an annual event dedicated to appreciation for the joys and love animals bring to our lives. Celebrated since 2006, it is a day to give special recognition to all of the wonderful pets that bring so much joy to our lives, and reflect on the importance of adoption and rescue. Give your pets some extra love today!

National Grilled Cheese Sandwich Day is celebrated annually on April 12th. The cheesy holiday honors the classic comfort food combo. First created by James L. Kraft in 1916, the modern grilled cheese has come to be an iconic American dish. In celebration of this delicious holiday, show your love for the classic sandwich by grilling up your favorite cheesy combo.

Celebrate National Scrabble Day on April 13th! This day celebrates America's favorite word game – first published in 1938. Play with friends and family to celebrate this classic game that has brought hours of enjoyment to those of all ages. Make this day a family tradition!

holiday_name: Look Up at the Sky Day
holiday_blurb: Look Up at the Sky day encourages people to enjoy the beauty of the sky. It is a great way to appreciate nature and enjoy the beauty of the sky. The special day began in 2017 by a passionate stargazer in the hope that people would look up and experience the wonders of the night sky.

National Laundry Day is a reminder to give your soiled clothes and linens some love. It was created in New York City by two sisters in 2007 and has turned into an annual holiday celebrated around the world. Take the time to clean, refresh, and honor the fabrics you wear with pride.

Celebrate your love of comfort with 'Wear Pajamas to Work Day'. Started in 2018 by the non-profit organization 'PJ Drive', it's a national day of joy celebrated on the last Monday in March. Join millions of people and show that leisurewear deserves a place in the office by wearing your pajamas to work. Who knows - maybe the tradition will stick!

Blah Blah Blah Day is an exciting celebration of joyful silliness! Its origins date back to the 1950s, when a group of pranksters used the "blah blah blah" phrase as a way to draw attention to the meaningless babble many people spoke in social situations. Celebrate today by pestering your friends with "blahs" and having a good laugh!

holiday_name: National Transfer Money to Your Daughter's Account Day
holiday_blurb: National Transfer Money to Your Daughter's Account Day is a holiday created to celebrate bonding between fathers and daughters. Created in 2012, this holiday encourages fathers to help their daughters build financial security by transferring money to their daughters' accounts. It is a day to remind fathers about the importance of financial education and security for their daughters.

National Garlic Day, held each April 19th, is a celebration of the beloved pungent bulb. It is said to have originated in San Rafael, California, where it was first celebrated back in the 1990’s. Today, it’s a global celebration of all things garlic! Enjoy garlic-infused dishes, explore the health benefits, and celebrate the unique taste of garlic!

Husband Appreciation Day, celebrated globally, is a day to recognize and honor husbands for all of their love and support. Established in 2004, this special day is the perfect opportunity to spark romance and appreciation in your relationship. Show your appreciation and let your partner know how much you care.

National Chocolate Covered Cashew Day is a holiday where people around the world come together to celebrate the delicious combination of cashews and chocolate. The holiday has been celebrated for many years and is a great opportunity to enjoy this tasty snack. Celebrate this year with friends and family by getting some chocolate covered cashews and savoring their perfect crunch and sweetness.

National Jelly Bean Day celebrates the delicious little pieces of goodness. Traditionally celebrated on April 22nd, it's impossible not to join in on the fun! Legends say its origin comes from Ronald Reagan who first declared the day as a way to honor the jelly Bean in the 80s. Celebrate with your family and friends!

A day to celebrate the iconic movie theater experience, Movie Theater Day is an unofficial holiday which marks the anniversary of the opening of the world's very first electrically operated movie theater back in 1895. Every year, fans of the silver screen indulge in the delight of the theater and head to their local cinema to relax and enjoy the newest blockbusters and timeless classics.

International Guide Dog Day is a day to celebrate the amazing partnership between guide dogs and their owners. Since the very first guide dog school opening in Germany in 1916, these animals have been providing independence and freedom to those who are visually impaired, and today there are countless stories of people who owe their lives to their brave canines. Join us in honoring these incredible animals who bring joy and hope to those who need it most! #InternationalGuideDogDay

National Mani-Pedi Day is celebrated every year and is dedicated to pampering hands and feet. This holiday encourages people to pamper themselves and show their hands and feet some love. Its history is believed to have started in the 1990s when nail salons began offering discounted services on this day.

Alien Day is an annual celebration of the iconic sci-fi movie franchise, Alien, that takes place each year in commemorance of the planet LV-426. Alien Day events are often fan-led, providing fans with activities and merchandise to mark the occasion.

Since the 1950s, this age-old tradition has brought families together around the world to share creative tales through story. Celebrate with old-fashioned campfire stories or more modern mediums like books and videos. Tell a Story Day is a great time for young and old to come together and create memories.

National Superhero Day celebrates the power of heroism each year! This holiday was created by Marvel fans in 1995 to honor all of their favorite superheroes and the positive values they embody. Join the celebration by dressing up as your favorite superhero, spreading acts of positivity, and cheering on the heroes in your life.

International Dance Day is celebrated annually on April 29th, to commemorate the birth of Jean-Georges Noverre, the creator of modern ballet. It's a day to celebrate the art of dance around the world, with people of all ages and styles. Everyone is encouraged to take part, and experience the joy of freely expressing themselves through dance.

International Jazz Day is a global event celebrated on April 30th every year. It was initiated in 2011 by UNESCO and the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz to recognize and honor jazz as a universal language of freedom, peace, unity, and intercultural dialogue. It celebrates jazz music around the world, recognizing the genre's role in uniting people from different backgrounds.

National Baked Alaska Day commemorates the dessert, a combination of sponge cake topped with ice cream and browned meringue, invented by Parisian chef Charles Francatelli in the 1840s. The dessert was popularized in the United States by Thomas Jefferson who enjoyed it after a trip to Monticello. Celebrate this delicious treat by baking one of your own!

National Ukulele Day is an international holiday established in 2018 by James Hill, an A-list ukulele artist and his wife throughout the world. The mission is to inspire others to pick up the ukulele and enjoy playing music with friends. Join the thousands of ukulele players and celebrate the joy of music-making!

Doggy Date Night, a special occasion for pup parents to bring their beloved pets to the local park and socialize, is an event that has been enjoyed for years. Held in the park, the evening consists of fun activities for both humans and puppies to meet, mingle, and bond. Bring your pup to make friends, enjoy some treats and make lasting memories.

Ice Cream for Breakfast Day is a wacky holiday devoted to the art of eating ice cream—for breakfast! Originating in the late 1950s, this unofficial holiday is designed to have children and adults alike step out of their comfort zones, and enjoy a delicious scoop of ice cream while the sun is still rising!

World Nutella Day celebrates the delicious hazelnut-chocolate spread. It was founded in 2007 by an American blogger determined to spread her love of Nutella, and is now celebrated with events, recipes, and parties all around the world! #WorldNutellaDay

Pay A Compliment Day encourages us to focus on positivity on this special day. Celebrated annually, the day was created in 1998 in Salinas, California by Debby Harold, a former teacher in the hopes of encouraging people to practice kindness, generosity, and appreciation. Take some time today to share simple compliments with everyone you encounter and make someone's day a bit brighter!

Celebrate National Fettucine Alfredo Day! Originally created in Rome in 1914, this classic dish is a blend of butter, parmesan cheese and cream tossed with fresh fettucine noodles. Enjoy it any way you like: plain, with chicken, with shrimp, or with your favorite vegetables. Delizioso!

Celebrate the joy of laughter and show the wealth of happiness on Laugh and Get Rich Day! This holiday has roots in the 1980s when author and humorist Larry Wilde proposed sharing laughter as a way to honor the rich human experience. Embrace the contagiousness of laughter and inspire your community to do the same.

Celebrate National Pizza Day on February 9th! This day has been celebrated since the early 1980s as a way to honor the iconic food from Italy. Whether you're a classic cheese fan, veggie enthusiast or an adventurous topping aficionado, everyone can enjoy this day for all things pizza!

National Flannel Day is a celebration of the traditional plaid shirt! It started in the 1990s as a grassroots movement to recognize the classic "uniform of the 90s" and has grown into a beloved holiday on the second Saturday of October each year. It's a chance to don your favorite flannel and celebrate with style!

National Guitar Day is a day to celebrate the world's favorite musical instrument- the guitar! Created in 1996, it is an international celebration of everything related to the guitar, such as its history, music, and culture. Let's come together and honor the people who have made, continue to make, and listen to beautiful music made with the guitar.

Plum Pudding, or Christmas Pudding, is a traditional British dessert dating back to the 1400s, made of sweet dried fruits, nuts, spices, and alcohol. Enjoy with whipped cream or custard - and be sure to have a slice for good luck!

Get a Different Name Day is an annual event that encourages people to change their name to something new. It's a chance to celebrate imagination and freedom of identity. The holiday began in California in 2004 and has since gained global recognition. Its goal is to inspire individuals to express their creativity and gain a newfound appreciation of their name.

International Book Giving Day celebrates the joy of giving books to those who need them most. It's a global event that recognizes the importance of reading and encourages people to donate books, both new and used, around the world. Started in 2012, this annual day has donated books to schools, libraries, and individuals in over 127 countries.

National Gumdrop Day is celebrated each year and is an opportunity for people to indulge in their favorite candy treats and share the sweet experience with friends and family. This holiday has its roots in the Victorian Era, when doctors would offer gumdrops to children in order to tempt them to take their medicines!

Innovation Day encourages innovative thinking. It started in 2019 and has since become a popular global event. Get creative and challenge yourself to find new solutions to existing problems. Celebrate the potential of a better future through creative thinking. #InnovationDay

Celebrate National Cabbage Day! This day is dedicated to recognizing the versatility and nutritional value of this humble vegetable. Cabbage has been cultivated since Ancient Roman times and the health benefits are still recognized today. So get your cabbage fix and enjoy this veggie in all its delicious forms!

Thumb Appreciation Day is a special day to celebrate the importance of thumbs! Celebrated annually, the day originally began as an internet movement to recognize thumbs for their extraordinary moments in history—modern technology, sign language, gesturing, and more! Get ready to give your thumbs a pat on the back!

Tug of War Day celebrates the beloved game of tug of war, believed to have originated with ancient Babylonian and Egyptian rope pulling contests. Enjoy this classic game to your heart's content, along with some friendly competition and an array of fun activities!

Hoodie Hoo Day is an unofficial holiday and is an opportunity to celebrate and express joy by sharing a spirited yell of "Hoodie-Hoo!" at noon. Some believe it dates back to pagan rituals from ancient times. Others say it's a modern-day tradition. Whether ancient or modern, it's a fun day to enjoy with friends or family.

Celebrate National Sticky Bun Day! A sweet and sticky sweet bun treat that dates back to the 1800s, sticky buns are both delicious and nostalgic. Enjoy one with a friend or treat yourself to this classic pastry.

Walking the Dog Day celebrates taking our furry friends for a stroll. It's an opportunity for pet owners to enjoy quality time with their dogs and enjoy the outdoors. It's also a way to remember a dog's importance and contribution in the lives of their owners and families.

Celebrate the winter sport of curling with Curling is Cool Day! This national Canadian holiday takes place yearly and pays homage to the game's rich history. Established in 2013, the day acknowledges the various cultural communities that have added their unique flair to this beloved winter pastime. Join in and show your curling spirit!

World Bartender Day celebrates the craft of bartending around the world, highlighting the importance bartenders have in connecting us to cultures and stories. First celebrated in 1989 by the International Bartenders Association, it is an international day of recognition for the work of bartenders around the world.

National Clam Chowder Day celebrates the creamy, comfort food dish enjoyed by many. The day celebrates the beloved chowder originating from the coasts of New England, which dates back to the 18th century. Each year, millions of Americans savor the flavors of this classic dish. So, join us on National Clam Chowder Day as we say cheers with a bowl of steaming, flavorful, and soulful clam chowder.

Carpe Diem Day marks a time for seizing the moment by appreciating and embracing the current day. It dates back to the Roman poet, Horace, who famously wrote the phrase in 23 BC, meaning "seize the day". This day serves as a reminder to pursue what our hearts desire and savor every moment.

International Polar Bear Day is celebrated every year to raise awareness about the importance of polar bear conservation. It was founded in 2015 by Polar Bears International, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the long-term survival of our planet's polar bears. The organization uses the day to promote positive action and dialogue about how to protect polar bear habitat and conserve the species.

National Tooth Fairy Day is celebrated every year. A fun event that marks childhood milestones, it commemorates the practice of placing teeth under a pillow and finding a gift in the morning. This beloved tradition dates back centuries, but the modern iteration of leaving a coin for a tooth was made popular by Disney in 1950.

Surf & Turf Day is an annual celebration of the beach, the ocean, and seafood. It is marked with events such as beach clean-ups, food festivals, and art installations. Originating from the Pacific Coast of California in the early 2000s, Surf & Turf day has become a global celebration of the ocean and its creatures.

Apple Gifting Day has been celebrated around the world since the late 90s, when the company first introduced Apple Macs. On this day, Apple fans come together to exchange gifts and celebrate the innovative products and ideas that have made the brand so iconic. Whether you're an Apple fan from the beginning or just getting started, join us this Apple Gifting Day and show your love for the brand!

Buffet Day honors the ubiquitous all-you-can-eat buffet. It is believed to have originated from an Italian tradition called "Gran Gasse", where large grape festivals were held with a host of incredible culinary masterpieces. Nowadays, Buffet Day is celebrated with family-style dinners, where guests stock up on favorites like salads, meats, seafood, and desserts!

Rooted in a tradition of dating back to the Victorian era, this fun-filled event encourages people to symbolically throw away their troubles by tossing a fruitcake. Now held in dozens of countries, it's the perfect way to end the year with a good laugh.

Trivia Day is an annual celebration rooted in knowledge, skill and community spirit. This day commemorates trivia games which have been popular across cultures for centuries. On this day, trivia-fanatics come together in teams to answer questions from a variety of topics, from history to sport to pop culture. Get ready to test your trivia knowledge and have some fun!

National Bird Day is an international celebration held annually to raise awareness about the protection and preservation of birds. Flying since 2005, the event encourages the public to appreciate their avian friends and when possible, to provide them with a safe habitat. It’s a celebration of avian diversity, as members of the public are encouraged to seek out, observe, and protect wild birds across the world.

National Shortbread Day is all about celebrating the tradition of baking the delicious crumbly Scottish biscuit! Shortbread first became popular in the 16th century as an exclusive treat for Royalty. Celebrated annually, bakers of all levels of skill come together to share in this timeless classic.

National Pass Gas Day is celebrated every year. This quirky holiday celebrates the natural response everyone experiences after eating certain foods, and encourages people to let it all out and not worry about it. It originally started as a prank between friends in 1998, and has since grown into a national holiday for gas-lovers everywhere.

holiday_name: Show and Tell at Work Day
holiday_blurb: Show and Tell at Work Day celebrates sharing knowledge and ideas among colleagues. It was created by Carrington Crowley, a renowned speaker, consultant and workplace adviser, to promote collaboration and open communication in the workplace. Every year on this day, employees have the opportunity to demonstrate skills and share experiences with their colleagues.

National Apricot Day is an annual celebration of one of the world’s oldest fruits. Originating in China over 4,000 years ago, apricot culture has spread across many countries and is celebrated by many. On this day, enjoy this sweet, juicy fruit by incorporating it into food, drinks, desserts, and more!

Peculiar People Day celebrates the uniqueness of every individual and honours those who have forged their own paths in life. It was created in 1993 by author Ron Elliott, who sought to call attention to individuality and create an occasion to offer thanks to those who live differently. Celebrate your uniqueness and be proud of your peculiarities!

National Take the Stairs Day is an annual event and its goal is to encourage people to take the stairs instead of elevators or escalators as an easy way to increase physical activity. The holiday has been celebrated since 2005, when the National Take the Stairs initiative began encouraging people to take the stairs for their health and wellbeing.

Celebrate National Hot Tea Day! Every year, people gather around a warm mug of tea in honor of a long-standing tradition of appreciating the comfort it brings. Its popularity can be traced back centuries to the 3rd century BC when it was used for medicinal purposes in China. From green to herbal, hot tea has become an integral part of cultures around the world.

National Rubber Ducky Day celebrates the iconic bath time toy we all know and love! The first rubber duck was created in the late 1800s and ever since then, duck-lovers have been celebrating this special day of appreciation each year. So grab your ducky and make some waves!

holiday_name: National Dress Up Your Pet Day
holiday_blurb: National Dress Up Your Pet Day is a day to love and appreciate your pet even more! On this day, owners celebrate their furry friends by dressing them up in fun outfits and capturing the moments in photos. This silly holiday has been celebrated since 2009 and is held every year. So get out your costumes and treats and join in the fun!

Commonly made of dough shaped into round, ring-like shapes, bagels are chewy and dense with loads of flavour. Bagels have been a classic staple of Jewish cuisine since the 17th century and today many different types and flavours are enjoyed around the world. Celebrate National Bagel Day with your favourite topping!

National Nothing Day is an annual holiday celebrated each year. It's purpose is to simply celebrate nothingness and nothing in particular. This day is a chance to take a break from all of the stresses of work, school, and the holiday season and just relax. The holiday has no real origin story, but it was created by newspaper reporter Harold Pullman Coffin in 1973.

National Hot Buttered Rum day is a day celebrating the classic hot winter beverage. Served warm, the spiced buttery rum drink has been around for centuries with historical roots that date back to colonial era America. Each year, celebrate the spirit of the season by enjoying a mug of this classic beverage.

Celebrate National Gourmet Coffee Day every year with a cup of your favorite java! This holiday highlights the appreciation of deliciously smooth, flavorful coffees. The tradition dates back to the early 19th century when new ways of roasting and blending beans started to emerge around the world. Celebrate with your favorite mug and a brew that's sure to please.

National Tin Can Day celebrates the invention of the tin can in 1810. This anniversary recognizes the first use of tin cans to preserve food by Nicolas Appert. Tin cans have become a staple of food preservation, living in our kitchen cupboards and refrigerators. Celebrate with a hearty home-cooked meal out of a tin can!

National Penguin Day is celebrated every year, and is a day dedicated to recognizing the adorable flightless birds. It is believed to have first been celebrated in the 1990's and remains a yearly occurrence enjoyed by wildlife enthusiasts. Fans of penguins are encouraged to observe the day by learning more about penguins and sharing their incredible characteristics with friends and family.

International Sweatpants Day is a day to celebrate the power of comfort. On International Sweatpants Day, which takes place annually, participants around the world wear sweatpants in celebration of leisure and relaxation. This fun and cheeky holiday was started in 2012 by the fashion company Gap.

holiday_name: National Answer Your Cat's Questions Day
holiday_blurb: National Answer Your Cat’s Questions Day is an annual holiday dedicated to understanding our furry feline friends. This day is devoted to pausing to contemplate what our cats may wonder about and attempting to answer to the best of our ability. It’s believed that this day was founded back in 2015, and has since gained popularity in many Cat Fancier clubs!

Celebrated each year, National Pie Day is an ode to the delicious desserts we have come to enjoy. This day was started in the mid-1970s by a nuclear physicist in Oregon. This yearly holiday has become an international event and a chance to seek out some of your favorite cakes and pies. Enjoy!

holiday_name: Talk Like A Grizzled Prospector Day
holiday_blurb: Talk Like A Grizzled Prospector Day celebrates the traditional slang used by 19th century prospectors. Participants adopt prospector lingo for a day, like "big as a barn door" or "clean as a hound's tooth", and have fun learning about this unique part of history.

Established to appreciate the beauty and science of meteorology, Observe the Weather Day also serves as an opportunity to raise awareness of the need to prepare for natural disasters. #ObserveTheWeatherDay

International Green Juice Day is an annual celebration of the health benefits of green juice. It celebrates the nutritional powerhouse that green juice is to enrich lives and boost overall health. This day was started by the Green Juice Movement - a group dedicated to highlighting the importance of vegetables and fruits in everyone’s diet. Join in the celebration - grab a kale, celery, cucumber, and apple smoothie and cheers to a healthier you! #InternationalGreenJuiceDay
Celebrate National Chocolate Cake Day every year! This day honors the delicious treat and has been celebrated since the early 1900s. Enjoy a slice (or two) and share the love with family and friends!

Pop Art Day celebrates the 1950s art movement which embraced popular culture images like comic books, advertising, and celebrity portraits. It's a day to appreciate the vibrant colors and bold lines of the iconic art, and to remember artists like Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein who were a major part of the movement.

National Corn Chip Day is a celebration of the salty, crunchy snack that is loved around the world. This holiday emerged in the 1940's with Fritos brand corn chips leading the way. Whether you prefer them with a dip or in a bowl of chili, take a moment to celebrate National Corn Chip Day!

Celebrate National Croissant Day! Enjoy a delicious layer of buttery pastry and a cup of joe. This special day originated as a tribute to the classic French pastry, first created in Austria in the 18th century. Now savor a modern twist on the beloved treat!

Eat Brussels Sprouts Day is a tribute to the vegetable with a long history. These bitter buds have been around since the 1200s, and for centuries have been enjoyed with a variety of tasty dishes. Join the festivities, indulge in your favorite Brussels sprout recipes, and don't forget to "EAT BRUSSELS"!

Extra Mile Day is an annual global celebration of goodness, kindness, and generosity, where people around the world go the extra mile and take time to do something special for one another. It was first celebrated in 2007 and has grown every year with people in more than 100 countries taking part.

National Deviled Egg Day celebrates the universal favorite snack. The creamy filling of boiled eggs and spicy condiments is a classic comfort food! Older recipes trace back to Ancient Rome, where it was called "ovum cube". Enjoy this delicious dish today! #NationalDeviledEggDay

Give Someone a Dollar Day began in 2002 with the aim of offering people an easy way to recognize the importance of kindness, with the simple gesture of 'paying it forward'. Every Give Someone a Dollar Day, take a dollar (or more!) from your pocket to give to a friend, or even a stranger, in need. Encouraging kindness has the power to make a real difference in people's lives.

Use Your Common Sense Day encourages us to make sensible decisions rather than rash ones. It's a day to think before you act, helping you create a life that reflects your true values. It was founded by Matthew Kelly, a best-selling author who believes making the right choices helps us live the best lives.

holiday_name: National Love Your Red Hair Day
holiday_blurb: National Love Your Red Hair Day is a day to embrace, support and celebrate those with red hair. It was founded by Emma Pattee in 2015 with the dream to create a community of redheads to share their stories and fight against bullying. Join the celebration, and spread the love for redheads worldwide! #LoveYourRedHairDay

National Saxophone Day celebrates the iconic instrument and its versatility, with performances of jazz, rock, blues, and classical music around the world. Since it was established in 1989, the day has become a celebration of the remarkable achievements of saxophonists throughout history.

Hug a Bear Day is a day to celebrate teddy bears and stuffed animals by giving them lots of hugs! It has been celebrated as early as 1907, when two Russian survivors of the Titanic found comfort in a teddy bear gifted to them by their rescuers. Celebrate this special day with a furry friend!

Cook Something Bold Day is an annual celebration of putting flavour first. On this day, people from all around the world challenge themselves to create an original and daring new dish. The event has been celebrated since 2011, with home cooks, celebrity chefs, and food fans uniting to bring their boldest recipes to life.

holiday_name: Go to an Art Museum Day
holiday_blurb: Go to an Art Museum Day is an international celebration of art, culture, and education. Every year, people around the world come together to visit local museums to learn about art history, appreciate unique artwork, and experience the creative power of collaboration. The day was founded in 2014 to promote the celebration and appreciation of art and artistic expression.

International Accounting Day celebrates the profound impact accountants and accounting principles have had on the world. Established in 1993 by the International Federation of Accountants, Accounting Day marks the way these principles facilitate global understanding by paving the way for communication and collaboration between nations.

World Origami Day is a celebration of the Japanese art of paper folding. Origami has been around since the 17th century and has grown in popularity worldwide. On World Origami Day, people learn about origami, practice the craft and share their creations. It's a fun, creative way to come together and share in the timeless tradition of paper folding !

Happy Hour Day is a festive day to celebrate the beginning of the weekend. This day is traditionally celebrated by getting together with friends and raising a toast to the fun times ahead. Many people enjoy unwinding with a cool beverage and catching up with friends on this day. The tradition began in the 1880s when bars and pubs started offering discount rates on drinks during certain hours of the day. Now, it is celebrated around the world and is widely seen as the best part of the work week.

World Kindness Day is celebrated every year to highlight good deeds and remind us of the importance of being kind. It was created in 1998 by the World Kindness Movement and many countries celebrate it as a way to encourage benevolence and altruism. Join in and give your part of kindness to others!

Celebrate National Pickle Day! Originated in the U.S. in the 1980s, this day acknowledges the cucumber-based treat's importance in many cultures. Enjoy pickles in all forms: pickled, fried, whole, or in a sandwich. Spread the pickle love!

Raisin Bran Cereal Day is celebrated annually to honor this beloved breakfast classic. It was introduced in the early 1930s by the Kellogg's company - a pioneering producer of ready-to-eat cereals. Raisin Bran's mix of crunchy bran flakes and sweet raisins makes it a nutritious and flavorful start to the day. Celebrate it by eating a bowl and savoring the taste!

National Fast Food Day is the ultimate celebration of all things quick and delicious! It commemorates the opening of the first fast-food restaurant, which was founded in 1919. Enjoy a jaunt to your local joint, and indulge in a guilty pleasure to honor this special day!

National Take a Hike Day is celebrated on the first Saturday of every November. This day encourages people to get out of their comfort zone and explore the outdoors. The day was founded in 2005 by the American Hiking Society to celebrate the joys of hiking and to promote healthy mental and physical exercise. So go on, dust off those hiking boots and find your favorite trail!

National Princess Day is a day to celebrate beauty, strength, and the universal power of female leadership. It was created to honor Princess Diana and her legacy of style, kindness, and grace, and is now observed around the world to recognize the contributions of modern-day princesses like Moana and Elsa. Celebrate National Princess Day by dressing up as your favorite princess or exploring the world of royal-inspired activities!

National Play Monopoly Day celebrates the iconic board game. Every year, avid fans and newcomers alike gather to play. Originating in 1933, it has been a beloved pastime for decades. Roll the dice and make your best moves!

Name Your PC Day celebrates the unique stories, people, and memories tied to our computers. From the first MacIntosh to modern day PC gamers, each PC is a living archive of our digital lives. Originally started in 1985, Name Your PC Day is a reminder to give our computers a person name — reflecting the memories and stories we have shared with them.

World Hello Day is an annual event that encourages peace and understanding between people of different cultures and faiths. Established in 1973 as a response to the Yom Kippur War, it promotes communication and connecting with each other to create a more peaceful environment. Millions of people around the world participate by simply saying hello to at least 10 people.

Go For a Ride Day encourages people to break out of their routine and explore the world by taking a scenic drive. Established in 1998 to honor the 70th anniversary of the AAA, it's an annual reminder to explore, connect with nature, and create memories.

National Espresso Day is celebrated in honour of the Italian drink. The drink has roots in Italian culture, tracing back to the early 1900s. Celebrate with a steaming cup of your favourite espresso blend - and don't forget the biscotti!

Celebrate Your Unique Talent Day is a great opportunity to embrace the unique skills that make you who you are. Founded to give people the confidence to embrace their talents in a lighthearted manner regardless of age or ability, this day has been celebrated worldwide for over 25 years. Why not take time to recognize your own special talents and celebrate the things that make you a unique individual?

Buy Nothing Day is an annual global event that encourages people to abstain from shopping, and take a day to think about their consumer habits and their impact on the planet. It was founded in 1992 by Canadian artist Ted Dave to raise awareness about overconsumption and the environmental destruction that society’s obsession with buying can cause.

National Cake Day is the perfect excuse to indulge in some delicious baked goods! Celebrated annually, National Cake Day stems from the tradition of baking cakes to celebrate Christmas; though usually made with festive spices and fruit, these cakes were often enjoy throughout the winter season. So take part in this tasty holiday and savor a scrumptious slice!

Pins and Needles Day originates from the British tradition that pins and needles were meant to bring good luck. The belief also suggests that leaving a pair of pins on the doorstep of a loved one will bring even more luck. On Pins and Needles Day, give and receive pins and needles for good luck, and be thankful for the extra luck you get this month!

Celebrate National French Toast Day! This sweet treat has been enjoyed for centuries, with its earliest known recipe dating back to the 4th or 5th century. Invite friends and family to share in the deliciousness of this classic breakfast favorite!

Electronic Greetings Day is a special day celebrated each year. It's a day to show your appreciation for friends and family by sending them something special. The day was created to bring a sense of fun to the internet, with e-cards, emails, and more. The date was chosen to honour a historic event: the first electronic greeting sent in 1994, by an ATP employee. Celebrate today - show your friends and family some love!

Computer Security Day, held annually, is an occasion to celebrate the advances in digital safety. It began in 1988 to raise awareness of the need to secure the use of computer technology and to promote security education. Celebrate and protect yourself by learning about the latest security methods.

holiday_name: National Eat a Red Apple Day
holiday_blurb: Celebrate the deliciousness of apples and the bounty of the autumn harvest on National Eat a Red Apple Day! Apples have been a popular food in many cultures and religions since antiquity. Enjoy some tart and juicy red apples on National Eat a Red Apple Day and appreciate the contribution of this healthy fruit to your diet and wellbeing!

Business of Popping Corn Day is an annual celebration that celebrates the production of popcorn. This holiday is celebrated each year and began in 1938 in recognition of the importance of popcorn in the U.S. economy. It's a day to recognize the farmers, entrepreneurs, and all those who have worked hard to make this tasty and nutritious snack a popular treat.

Make a Gift Day is a special day to share with those in need. It encourages individuals, organizations and groups to make homemade gifts or donate money or items to those who don't have the means to provide for themselves. The tradition started over 20 years ago and has since been embraced by people throughout the world. Show someone you care by participating in Make a Gift Day!

National Sock Day is a day to celebrate the fun and comfort of everyone's favorite foot accessory! It's celebrated every year and is believed to have started in the USA back in 2016 as a way to encourage people to donate new socks to those in need. Celebrate the versatile power of the humble sock - wear your wildest, craziest pair!

National Blue Jeans Day is an annual celebration of denim and its role in American culture. Every year since 2003, people around the world have gathered to recognize the benefits of jeans, from its comfort to its practicality. Jeans originated in the 19th century as bib overalls, becoming popular among American blue-collar workers. Today, it is one of the most universally beloved sartorial choices, making appearances in both everyday wardrobes and on the runways!

National Microwave Oven Day celebrates the invention of the microwave oven. Released in 1967, this revolutionary kitchen appliance changed the way we cook. Celebrate this day with a meal cooked in the the microwave— just be sure to heat it up for no longer than a minute or two!

Letter Writing Day celebrates the timeless art of sending letters. From heartfelt thank-yous to well-wishes, this day encourages us to express ourselves through writing, one stitch at a time. With a history dating back to the 16th century, letter writing is a classic pursuit shared by people of all ages and backgrounds. Step away from the screen and put pen to paper today!

National Brownie Day is celebrated each year in honour of the unique chocolate treat. Thought to have first appeared in recipes in America in the late 19th century, brownies are a beloved dessert. Celebrate National Brownie Day by indulging in your favourite variety!

National Llama Day is an unofficial holiday celebrating the majesty of the llama. It was founded in 2011 by llama lovers around the world as a day to appreciate and learn about the animals. Since then, National Llama Day has become an international phenomenon, with events and activities held globally to honor the beloved species.

International Animal Rights Day is a global event held annually to celebrate, recognize, and protect the rights of animals around the world. It has been celebrated since 2002, with the aim of raising awareness of the often-unmentioned mistreatment of animals, and the need for their rights to be respected.

On National Have a Bagel Day, enjoy a bagel with your favorite topping and honor the time-honored tradition of bagel baking. Bagels have been a part of New York culture since the late 1800's when Eastern European Jews settled in the area. Celebrated for their delicious flavor and convenience, bagels are an integral part of life in the United States. Today, it's a great way to recognize this unique food item and enjoy a delicious

Gingerbread House Day celebrates the whimsical and beloved tradition of creating and decorating edible houses. Dating back to 16th century Germany, when gingerbread houses became popular with folk tales of Hansel and Gretel, this sweet holiday encourages creativity and delight. Bake, decorate, and share the love!

National Violin Day is a day to celebrate the beloved instrument and recognize its storied history. Celebrated annually, the day first became popular in 2015 as a way to highlight the violin's unique sound and diverse range of musical styles. Celebrate by picking up your violin and playing a tune!

Monkey Day is celebrated annually and is a day to celebrate primates of all kinds! It’s also a great day to recognize the important role monkeys play in our world, from wildlife conservation to medical research. The day was created in 2000 by artists Casey Sorrow and Eric Millikin as a fun way to recognize and celebrate primates.

National Cat Herders Day recognizes the hard work of all those (human or feline) in the creative and challenging profession of feline herding. With roots tracing back to a series of humorous advertisements in the 1970s, the day is an opportunity to recognize the unique skills and dedication required of "cat herders" all over the world.

Stupid Toy Day is an annual, worldwide celebration of silly and whimsical toys. It was created in 1999 and brings joy by encouraging people to get playful and share toys with friends. It's a day to tap into your inner child and have fun!

Celebrate National Maple Syrup Day! The sweet holiday started in Canada in 1991 to recognize the history of maple syrup production, from the first Native American tribes to the modern syrup industry today. Enjoy some delicious syrup on this special day.

National Roast Suckling Pig Day celebrates the joy of roasting a whole pig, a traditional feast found all around the world. The popularity of roasting suckling pigs dates back to the ancient Greeks and Romans, who reveled in the delicacy of slow roasted pork. Celebrate by inviting friends for dinner, and be sure to give thanks for such a delicious pig!

National Emo Day is a worldwide celebration of emo music and culture. Founded in 2015, the holiday commemorates the emo subculture which consists of fashion, music, and attitude and celebrates its impact around the world. From capturing the emotional struggles of the youth to helping spread the power of acceptance and resilience, National Emo Day is an opportunity to recognize and honor its influence. #emo4life

Games Day is an annual event that brings together thousands of enthusiastic gamers from around the world. It gives them the chance to play and compete in a variety of different games and to meet like-minded gamers from different countries. From tabletop games to esports, digital games to retro gaming, and more, Games Day has something for everyone. The event first began in the late-1970s and has grown to become one of the biggest gaming gatherings in the world.

Celebrate Crossword Puzzle Day on December 21! This holiday commemorates Arthur Wynne's first published crossword in the New York World in 1913. Challenge yourself and others to test their wits and have fun in the process!

Celebrated annually, National Cookie Exchange Day is the perfect excuse to get together with friends, family, and colleagues to share and swap your favorite recipes! It's a time-honored tradition that is said to date back to the 1800s, when neighbors would come together to swap their unique recipes and stories in an effort to bring a little joy to the holiday season.

Celebrate National Pfeffernusse Day each year by enjoying this traditional German cookie! The cakey spiced cookie is believed to have originated in Germany in medieval times, but it is a holiday staple in many cultures today!

National Eggnog Day celebrates one of the most beloved holiday beverages: eggnog. Originating in medieval Britain, it eventually made its way to the United States and is now enjoyed around the world. From spiced to baileys-infused, celebrate this holiday classic with friends and family.

National Pumpkin Day is an annual event for cooking, baking, carving, decorating, or simply enjoying pumpkins. The tradition of eating pumpkins for Halloween dates back to early immigrants who brought the practice of carving turnips to the U.S. and replaced them with pumpkins.

Celebrated since the early 20th century, National Candy Cane Day remembers the classic Christmas treat and is a reminder that the holiday season isn’t over yet! Legend has it that in 1670, a German choirmaster handed out white candies in the shape of a shepherd's crook as a token of appreciation to the kids in his choir.
